election_record.label: New Hampshire 1803 Governor

overview.note: The state of New Hampshire released official totals for the state but not for individual counties or towns. Nor did the state release a list of the towns that were rejected. As a result, the town and county totals do not add up to the stated official state totals.

sub_unit.name: Chesterfield
sub_unit.note: The New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) and Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) list John Langdon with 11 votes.

sub_unit.name: Concord
sub_unit.note: "Note this is the highest vote given during the day - the vote for Representatives, was 248, thirty less! How the Yeomanry of Concord, could thus come forward in their federal zeal, and give a majority to Mr. Gilman, over Mr. Langdon, (when it is well known that the one has always been inimical to the town of Concord, and the other has been uniformly friendly to it) - can be accounted for on no rational principles: It is a solecism of conduct, that nothing but federal witchcraft can reconcile." American Republican Gazette (Concord, NH). March 10, 1803.

"There were 140 votes last year for Col. Langdon in Concord. The small deficiency of 10 the present year was from the cause of a number of republicans being absent in procuring timber for the new (federal) bridge. Had all the republicans been present, Mr. Langdon would have received some accession of votes the present year. The extra number of votes given for Gov. G was either owing to many's being induced to vote for him by the violent exertions of his particular friends in this place, who have not usually voted at all, or to some other reason that cannot at present be accounted for." American Republican Gazette (Concord, NH). March 10, 1803.

"Votes for Governor, (first balloting) John T. Gilman 142, John Langdon 137 - The friends of Mr. Langdon, finding their candidate's scale was likely to kick the beam, complained that they had not had a fair chance; on which the people were indulged with a second balloting, when John T. Gilman had 148, and John Langdon 130!" Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH). March 12, 1803.
Concord Town Records list the first vote of John T. Gilman with 142 votes and John Langdon with 137 votes.
